com.salesforce.omakase.ast

Class Comment

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.salesforce.omakase.ast.Comment
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Writable

    public final class Comment
extends Object
implements Writable
    Represents a CSS comment.

    By default, comments are not written out. You can control this behavior with StyleWriter.writeAllComments(boolean).

    • Constructor Summary

      Comment(CssAnnotation annotation)
      Creates a new Comment with the given CssAnnotation as the content.

      Creates a new Comment with the given content.

    • Method Detail

      • content

        public String content()
        Gets the content of the comment.
        Returns:

      • hasAnnotation

        public boolean hasAnnotation(String name)
        Checks if this comment has a CssAnnotation with the given name.

        CSS comment annotations are CSS comments that contain an annotation in the format of "@annotationName [optionalArgs]", for example "@noparse", "@browser ie7", etc...

        Only one annotation per comment block is allowed.

        Parameters:
        name - Check for an annotation with this name.
        Returns:
        True if a CssAnnotation was found with the given name.

      • hasAnnotation

        public boolean hasAnnotation(CssAnnotation annotation)
        Checks if this comment has a CssAnnotation that equals the given one.

        This will be true if the both the name and the args match exactly. See CssAnnotation.equals(Object). If you only care about matching the comment name, see hasAnnotation(String) instead.

        Parameters:
        annotation - Check for an annotation that equals this one.
        Returns:
        True if a Comment was found that matches the given one.

      • annotation

        public Optional<CssAnnotation> annotation(String name)
        Gets the CssAnnotation with the given name, if there is one.

        CSS comment annotations are CSS comments that contain an annotation in the format of "@annotationName [optionalArgs]", for example "@noparse", "@browser ie7", etc...

        Only one annotation per comment block is allowed.

        Parameters:
        name - Get the annotation with this name.
        Returns:
        The CssAnnotation, or an empty Optional if not found.

      • annotation

        public Optional<CssAnnotation> annotation()
        Gets the CssAnnotation within this comment, if there is one.

        CSS comment annotations are CSS comments that contain an annotation in the format of "@annotationName [optionalArgs]", for example "@noparse", "@browser ie7", etc...

        Only one annotation per comment block is allowed.

        Returns:
        The CssAnnotation, or an empty Optional if not found.

      • startsWithBang

        public boolean startsWithBang()
        Returns whether the comment starts with ! (this is strict, no whitespace allowed between the opening comment and the bang).
        Returns:
        True if the comment starts with '!'.

      • isWritable

        public boolean isWritable()
        Description copied from interface: Writable
        Returns whether this unit should actually be written.

        Usually this should just return true, however some units that are detachable or otherwise potentially invalid should first check their state and respond appropriately.

        Specified by:
        isWritable in interface Writable
        Returns:
        True if the unit should be written.

      • write

        public void write(StyleWriter writer,
                  StyleAppendable appendable)
           throws IOException
        Description copied from interface: Writable
        Outputs this Writable's string representation.

        Important notes for implementation:

        Do not use the StyleWriter in an attempt to write direct content (Strings, chars, etc...). Use the StyleAppendable.

        The StyleWriter should be used to make decisions based on writer settings (e.g., compressed vs. verbose output mode), as well as for writing inner or child Writables. Do not call the this method method directly on inner or child Writables! That would bypass any overrides that are set on the StyleWriter. Use StyleWriter.writeInner(Writable, StyleAppendable) instead.

        Specified by:
        write in interface Writable
        Parameters:
        writer - Writer to use for output settings and for writing inner Writables.
        appendable - Append direct content to this StyleAppendable.
        Throws:
        IOException - If an I/O error occurs.
